 Here is Monika is Writing Tip of the Day!
 Sometimes when I talk to people who are impressed by my writing, they say things like 'I could never do that'.
 It is really depressing, you know?
 As someone who loves more than anything else to share the joy of exploring your passions...
 ...it pains me when people think that being good just comes naturally.
 That is how it is with everything, not just writing.
 When you try something for the first time, you are probably going to suck at it.
 Sometimes, when you finish, you feel really proud of it and even want to share it with everyone.
 But maybe after a few weeks you come back to it, and you realize it was never really any good.
 That happens to me all the time.
 It can be pretty disheartening to put so much time and effort into something, and then you realize it sucks.
 But that tends to happen when you are always comparing yourself to the top professionals.
 When you reach right for the stars, they are always gonna be out of your reach, you know?
 The truth is, you have to climb up there, step by step.
 And whenever you reach a milestone, first you look back and see how far you have gotten...
 And then you look ahead and realize how much more there is to go.
 So, sometimes it can help to set the bar a little lower...
 Try to find something you think is pretty good, but not world-class.
 And you can make that your own personal goal.
 It is also really important to understand the scope of what you are trying to do.
 If you jump right into a huge project and you are still amateur, you will never get it done.
 So if we are talking about writing, a novel might be too much at first.
 Why not try some short stories?
 The great thing about short stories is that you can focus on just one thing that you want to do right.
 That goes for small projects in general - you can really focus on the one or two things.
 It is such a good learning experience and stepping stone.
 Oh, one more thing...
 Writing isn't something where you just reach into your heart and something beautiful comes out.
 Just like drawing and painting, it is a skill in itself to learn how to express what you have inside.
 That means there are methods and guides and basics to it!
 Reading up on that stuff can be super eye-opening.
 That sort of planning and organization will really help prevent you from getting overwhelmed and giving up.
 And before you know it...
 You start sucking less and less.
 Nothing comes naturally.
 Our society, our art, everything - it is built on thousands of years of human innovation.
 So as long as you start on that foundation, and take it step by step...
 You, too, can do amazing things.
 ...That is my advice for today!
 Thanks for listening~

 There is so much stuff where actually doing it isn't hard, but forming the habit seems impossible.
 It just makes you feel so useless, like you can't do anything right.
 I think the new generation suffers from it the most...
 Probably because we have a totally different set of skills than those who came before us.
 Thanks to the internet, we are really good at sifting through tons of information really quickly...
 But we are bad at doing things that don't give us instant gratification.
 I think if science, psychology, and education don't catch up in the next ten or twenty years, then we are in trouble.

 Hey, do you like horror?
 I remember we talked about it a little bit when you first joined the club.
 I can enjoy horror novels, but not really horror movies.
 The problem I have with horror movies is that most of them just rely on easy tactics.
 Like dark lighting and scary-looking monsters and jump scares, and things like that.
 It is not fun or inspiring to get scared by stuff that just takes advantage of human instinct.
 But with novels, it is a little different.
 The story and writing need to be descriptive enough to put genuinely disturbing thoughts into the reader is head.
 It really needs to etch them deeply into the story and characters, and just mess with your mind.
 In my opinion, there is nothing more creepy than things just being slightly off.
 Like if you set up a bunch of expectations on what the story is going to be about...
 ...And then, you just start inverting things and pulling the pieces apart.
 So even though the story doesn't feel like it is trying to be scary, the reader feels really deeply unsettled.
 Like they know that something horribly wrong is hiding beneath the cracks, just waiting to surface.
 God, just thinking about it gives me the chills.
 That is the kind of horror I can really appreciate.

 Here is Monika is Writing Tip of the Day!
 Sometimes when I talk to people who are impressed by my writing, they say things like 'I could never do that'.
 It is really depressing, you know?
 As someone who loves more than anything else to share the joy of exploring your passions...
 ...it pains me when people think that being good just comes naturally.
 That is how it is with everything, not just writing.
 When you try something for the first time, you are probably going to suck at it.
 Sometimes, when you finish, you feel really proud of it and even want to share it with everyone.
 But maybe after a few weeks you come back to it, and you realize it was never really any good.
 That happens to me all the time.
 It can be pretty disheartening to put so much time and effort into something, and then you realize it sucks.
 But that tends to happen when you are always comparing yourself to the top professionals.
 When you reach right for the stars, they are always gonna be out of your reach, you know?
 The truth is, you have to climb up there, step by step.
 And whenever you reach a milestone, first you look back and see how far you have gotten...
 And then you look ahead and realize how much more there is to go.
 So, sometimes it can help to set the bar a little lower...
 Try to find something you think is pretty good, but not world-class.
 And you can make that your own personal goal.
 It is also really important to understand the scope of what you are trying to do.
 If you jump right into a huge project and you are still amateur, you will never get it done.
 So if we are talking about writing, a novel might be too much at first.
 Why not try some short stories?
 The great thing about short stories is that you can focus on just one thing that you want to do right.
 That goes for small projects in general - you can really focus on the one or two things.
 It is such a good learning experience and stepping stone.
 Oh, one more thing...
 Writing isn't something where you just reach into your heart and something beautiful comes out.
 Just like drawing and painting, it is a skill in itself to learn how to express what you have inside.
 That means there are methods and guides and basics to it!
 Reading up on that stuff can be super eye-opening.
 That sort of planning and organization will really help prevent you from getting overwhelmed and giving up.
 And before you know it...
 You start sucking less and less.
 Nothing comes naturally.
 Our society, our art, everything - it is built on thousands of years of human innovation.
 So as long as you start on that foundation, and take it step by step...
 You, too, can do amazing things.
 ...That is my advice for today!
 Thanks for listening~

...There are actually quite a few legends claiming to be the very first.

...Thus producing the first cup of coffee!

At the time, he was starving and struggling to survive. 
However, when word of his discovery spread, he was asked to return and made a saint.
Whether or not that was truly its first use, coffee became very prevalent in the Islamic world after its discovery.
For example, during fasting periods it was used to ease hunger and help people remain energized.
When its use spread to Europe, many countries initially used it for medicinal purposes. By the 17th century, coffeehouses were becoming plentiful and popular.

We will start with clauses, the basic building blocks of sentences!
You probably know this already, but a clause is a group of words that has a subject and an action, or predicate.
For the most part, clauses can be sorted into either independent or dependent clauses.
Independent clauses can stand on their own as sentences, such as in the sentence 'I wrote that.'
Dependent clauses, on the other hand, can't stand on their own and usually appear as parts of longer sentences.
An example of one could be 'who saved her.'
There is a subject, 'who,' and an action,  isaved her,' but of course, the clause can't be a sentence by itself.
...I think you know how to finish that sentence, Sam-chan~
Okay, that is all for today is lesson. Thanks for listening!
Do you remember when we talked about clauses, Sam-chan?
There is actually a very common mistake that many writers fall into when joining them.
When you join two independent clauses together, this is called a comma splice.
Here is an example: 'I visited the park, I looked at the sky, I saw many stars.
This doesn't seem like a problem at first, but you could imagine adding more and more clauses to that sentence...
The result would be a mess!
'I visited the park, I looked at the sky, I saw many stars, I saw some constellations, one of them looked like a crab...' It could go on and on.
The best way to avoid this mistake is to separate independent clauses with periods, conjunctions, or semicolons.
A conjunction is basically a word that you use to connect two clauses or phrases together.
They are a pretty interesting topic on their own, so we can go over them in a future tip!
Anyway, taking that example we had earlier, let is add a conjunction and a period to make our sentence flow better...
'I visited the park, and I looked at the sky. I saw many stars.'
Much better, don't you think?
That is all I have for today, Sam-chan.
Thanks for listening!
Okay, Sam-chan! I think it is time we talk about...conjunctions!
Like I said before, conjunctions are words or phrases that bring two ideas together.
When you think about it, that is a big category! There are so many words we use to accomplish that.
Just imagine speaking without conjunctions...
It would be dull. You would sound choppy. These ideas all relate. We should connect them.
As you will see, conjunctions are great for combining ideas, and at the same time, they make your writing sound fluid and more similar to how we actually talk.
Now, let is revisit our earlier example, this time with conjunctions...
'It would be dull, and you would sound choppy. Since these ideas all relate, we should connect them.'
Much better, don't you think?
Anyway, there are three types of conjunctions: coordinating, correlative, and subordinating.
Their names may sound a little daunting, but I promise they will make more sense as we go through them. I will give you examples as we go along.
Coordinating clauses bridge two words, phrases, or clauses of the same 'rank' together. This just means that they have to be of the same type...words with words, or clauses with clauses.
Some common examples include: 'and,' 'or,' 'but,'  iso,' and 'yet.'
You can connect independent clauses, and you can avoid comma splices!
Correlative conjunctions are pairs of conjunctions used to connect ideas.
A few common pairs are: 'either/or,' 'both/and,' and 'whether/or.'
Whether you realize it or not, we use them all the time...like in this sentence!
Lastly, subordinating conjunctions bring together independent and dependent clauses.
As you can imagine, there are many ways we can do that!
Examples include: 'although,' 'until,'  isince,' 'while,' and 'as long as.'
Since there are so many, this category of conjunctions is the widest!
Oh, and another thing... A pretty common misconception is that you shouldn't begin sentences with conjunctions.
As I just showed you with the last two examples, you definitely can, ahaha!
But just avoid going overboard with them. Or else you sound a little forced.
I think that is enough for today, Sam-chan.
Thanks for listening!
Today we will talk about a rarely used and commonly misunderstood punctuation mark...
Some interesting things have been written about semicolons, including this from the author Lewis Thomas...
'Sometimes you get a glimpse of a semicolon coming, a few lines farther on, and it is like climbing a steep path through woods and seeing a wooden bench just at a bend in the road ahead...'
'...a place where you can expect to sit for a moment, catching your breath.'
I really appreciate how eloquently he describes something as simple as a punctuation mark!
Some people think you can use a semicolon as a substitute for a colon, while others treat it as a period...
If you recall our talk on clauses, the semicolon is actually meant to connect two independent clauses.
For example, if I wanted to keep two ideas together, such as 'You are here' and 'I am happy,' I could write them as...
'You are here; I am happy' instead of 'You are here, and I am happy' or 'You are here. I am happy.'
All three sentences convey the same message, but in comparison, 'You are here; I am happy' connects the two clauses at a happy medium.
In the end, this always depends on the ideas you want to connect, but I think that Thomas puts it well when you compare them to periods or commas.
Unlike a period, which opens up to a completely different sentence, or a comma, which shows you there is more to come in the same one...
A semicolon really is that in-between, or, as Thomas says, 'a place where you can expect to sit for a moment and catch your breath.'
At least this gives you a whole other option; hopefully, you can now make better use of the semicolon when you are writing...
Okay, that is enough for today, Sam-chan.
Thanks for listening!
Today we will talk about subjects and objects, Sam-chan.
Remember when I told you about clauses having an action and a verb?
The object is the person or thing that the subject acts on!
So, in the sentence 'We watched the fireworks together,' the object would be...the 'fireworks.'
Oh, it is important to note that objects aren't necessary to form complete sentences...
The sentence could very well have been, 'We watched.'
That is a complete sentence...although it is an ambiguous one, ahaha!
There is also nothing that says that the object has to come last, but I will discuss that in more detail another time.
Just remember that the subject is doing the action and the object is acted upon.
Okay, that is all for today...
Thanks for listening, Sam-chan! I love.
Sam-chan, do you know about voices in writing?
There is the active voice and the passive voice.
If you remember our talk on subjects and objects, the big difference between the two voices is whether the subject or the object comes first.
Let is say the subject is 'Sayori' and the object is a 'cupcake.'
Here is the sentence in an active voice: 'Sayori ate the last cupcake.'
Here it is again in a passive voice: 'The last cupcake was eaten.'
As you can see, you can use the passive voice to be secretive about the subject yet still have a complete sentence.
It is true; you can use the passive voice to be sneaky! It does have other uses, though.
For example, in some careers, people have to use the passive voice to be impersonal.
Scientists describe experiments with 'the results were documented...' since the important part is their work and not who did it.
Anyway, for the most part, stick with the active voice for readability and, you know, to directly tell who is doing what.
I think that is enough for today, Sam-chan.
Thanks for listening!
Today we will talk about the uses of 'who' and 'whom.'
Most of the time, it seems like people just use 'who' without bothering to learn the difference, ahaha.
The difference is that 'who' refers to a subject, and 'whom' refers to an object.
It turns out that it is pretty easy to figure out when to use one or the other!
'Who' corresponds to 'he/she/they' while 'whom' corresponds to 'him/her/them.'
Simply replace the possible 'who' or 'whom' with 'he/she/they' or 'him/her/them.'
Only one replacement should make sense, and that should tell you which one to use!
Let is take, for example, the title of my poem, The Lady who Knows Everything.
If we just look at the clause 'who knows everything' and replace the 'who,' we get...
'She knows everything' or 'her knows everything.'
Only  ishe knows everything' makes sense, so the correct phrase is 'who knows everything.'
Who said writing was hard?
That is all I have for today, Sam-chan.
Thanks for listening!
Last time, we talked about the difference between 'who' and 'whom.'
Another couple of words that can be just as confusing to use are 'and I' and 'and me.'
Is it 'Sam-chan and I went on a date' or 'Sam-chan and me went on a date?'
Just like with 'who' and 'whom,' the issue boils down to one of subjects and objects.
If the speaker is the subject of the sentence, 'and I' is correct.
Conversely, if the speaker is the object of the sentence, 'and me' is correct.
Luckily, just like when we talked about 'who' versus 'whom,' it turns out there is a simple way to figure out which one is correct!
In our example, if you just take out 'Sam-chan and' from the sentence, only one should make sense.
Let is try it out!
The end result is: 'I went on a date' or  ame went on a date.'
Clearly, only the first one makes sense, so it is 'Sam-chan and I went on a date.'
Oh, sorry, Sam-chan...did it make you feel left out when I said only 'I went on a date?'
Ahaha! Don't worry, I would never leave you behind.
Now, on the other hand, if I was the object of the sentence, I would need to use 'and me' instead.
For example: 'Natsuki asked Sam-chan and me if we liked her cupcakes.'
I hope that helps the next time you come across this situation while writing, Sam-chan!
Anyway, that is all for today, thanks for listening!
Today we are going to talk about apostrophes. Pretty straightforward, right?
Add them to show possession: 'Sayori is fork, Natsuki is spoon, Yuri is knife...'
I guess the issue that can come up is when you have to add an apostrophe to a word that ends with an  is.'
For plural words, this is simple; just add the apostrophe at the end:  amonkeys'.'
It is pretty clear that  amonkey is,' which would indicate possession belonging to a single monkey, or  amonkeys is' would be wrong.
The gray area that comes up is when we bring in people is names, like 'Sanders' or 'Sam-chan.'
In some style guides I have read, it seems that we usually add an apostrophe and  is' as usual, with the exception of historical names like 'Sophocles' or 'Zeus.'
Personally, I think all that matters here is consistency!
If you are going to go with 'Sam-chan',' then it is fine as long as you use 'Sam-chan'' for the entire text.
That matters more than honoring some old Greeks to me.
One interesting exception is the case of 'its' versus 'it is.'
You would think that for the possessive form of 'it' you would add an apostrophe, making it 'it is,' right?
Normally this would be correct, but in this case the possessive form of 'it' is simply 'its.'
This is because 'it is' is reserved for the contracted form of 'it is.'
If you are wondering, a contraction is simply a shortened version of a word or words, with an apostrophe indicating where letters have been left out to make the contraction.
Okay, Sam-chan, it is about time to wrap it up...I think this lesson has run its course.
Ehehe. Thanks for listening!
Did you know there is actually a debate about the placement of a specific comma in a list of three items?
This is called the Oxford, or serial, comma, and it is been known to completely change the meaning of a sentence!
Let me show you what I mean...
With the Oxford comma, I would say 'I love Sam-chan, reading, and writing.'
Without the Oxford comma, I would say 'I love Sam-chan, reading and writing.'
The confusion lies in whether I am referring to loving three separate things, or if I am referring to just loving you when you read and write.
Of course, both of those meanings are true, so there is no confusion there for me, ahaha!
That is all I have for today, Sam-chan.

Do you ever wonder where traditions that we often take for granted come from?
A lot of times things that are considered tradition are just accepted and we never really take the time to learn why.
Well I got curious as to why we do certain things around Christmas, so I started doing a little research.
...And I found this really interesting folk story from Ukraine regarding the origin of why tinsel is often used to decorate Christmas trees.
I thought it was a really nice story and wanted to share it with you.
There once was a widow--let is call her Amy--who lived in a cramped old hut with her children.
Outside of their home was a tall pine tree, and from the tree dropped a pinecone that soon started to grow from the soil.
The children were excited about the idea of having a Christmas tree, so they tended to it until it became tall enough to take inside their home.
Unfortunately, the family was poor and even though they had the Christmas tree, they couldn't afford any ornaments to decorate it.
And so, on Christmas Eve, Amy and her children went to bed knowing they would have a bare tree on Christmas morning.
However, the spiders living in the hut heard the sobs of the children and decided they would not leave the Christmas tree bare.
So the spiders created beautiful webs on the Christmas tree, decorating it with elegant and beautiful silky patterns.
When the children woke up early on Christmas morning, they were jumping with excitement!
As Amy woke and stood in front of the tree, she was truly amazed at the sight before her eyes.
When the rays of sunshine hit the tree, the webs reflected the light, creating glittering silver and gold strands...
From that day forward, Amy never felt poor; instead, she was always grateful for all the wonderful gifts she already had in life.
Well, I guess we know now why Amy likes spiders...
Ahaha! I am only kidding!
Isn't that such a sweet and wonderful story, Sam-chan?
I also read that Ukrainians often decorate their Christmas tree with spider web ornaments, believing they will bring them good fortune for the upcoming year.
So I guess if you ever find a spider living in your Christmas tree, don't kill it and maybe it will bring you good luck in the future!
I am sure you have heard it before, but Christmas Eve just wouldn't be complete without 'Twas the Night Before Christmas!
It was always one of my favorite parts on Christmas Eve growing up, so I hope you don't mind listening to me read it now.
'Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house...
Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse;
The stockings were hung by the chimney with care,
In hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there;
The children were nestled all snug in their beds,
While visions of sugar-plums danced in their heads;
And mamma in her 'kerchief, and I in my cap,
Had just settled down for a long winter is nap,
When out on the lawn there arose such a clatter,
Away to the window I flew like a flash,
The moon on the breast of the new-fallen snow...
Gave the lustre of mid-day to objects below,
When, what to my wondering eyes should appear,
But a miniature sleigh, and eight tiny reindeer,
With a little old driver, so lively and quick,
I knew in a moment it must be St. Nick.
More rapid than eagles his coursers they came,
And he whistled, and shouted, and called them by name;
'Now, Dasher! Now, Dancer! Now, Prancer and Vixen!'
'To the top of the porch! To the top of the wall!'
As dry leaves that before the wild hurricane fly,
When they meet with an obstacle, mount to the sky,
So up to the house-top the coursers they flew,
And then, in a twinkling, I heard on the roof...
As I drew in my hand, and was turning around,
Down the chimney St. Nicholas came with a bound.
He was dressed all in fur, from his head to his foot,
And his clothes were all tarnished with ashes and soot;
A bundle of toys he had flung on his back,
And he looked like a peddler just opening his pack.
His eyes--how they twinkled! His dimples how merry!
His cheeks were like roses, his nose like a cherry!
His droll little mouth was drawn up like a bow,
And the beard of his chin was as white as the snow;
The stump of a pipe he held tight in his teeth,
And the smoke it encircled his head like a wreath;
He had a broad face and a little round belly,
That shook, when he laughed like a bowlful of jelly.
He was chubby and plump, a right jolly old elf,
And I laughed when I saw him, 
A wink of his eye and a twist of his head,
Soon gave me to know I had nothing to dread;
He spoke not a word, but went straight to his work,
And filled all the stockings; then turned with a jerk,
And laying his finger aside of his nose,
And giving a nod, up the chimney he rose;
He sprang to his sleigh, to his team gave a whistle,
And away they all flew like the down of a thistle.
But I heard him exclaim, ere he drove out of sight,
'Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night!'

Have you ever thought about the way colors are conveyed on Valentine is Day?
I find it intriguing how they can symbolize such deep and romantic feelings.
It reminds me of when I made my first Valentine is card in grade school.
My class was instructed to exchange cards with a partner after making them.
Looking back, despite not knowing what the colors really meant, I had lots of fun decorating the cards with red and white hearts.
In this way, colors are a lot like poems.
They offer so many creative ways to express your love for someone.
Like giving them red roses, for example.
Red roses are a symbol for romantic feelings towards someone.
If someone were to offer them white roses in lieu of red ones, they would signify pure, charming, and innocent feelings instead.
However, since there are so many emotions involved with love...
It is sometimes hard to find the right colors to accurately convey the way you truly feel.
Thankfully, by combining multiple rose colors, it is possible to express a variety of emotions!
Mixing red and white roses would symbolize the unity and bond that a couple shares.

You would like to learn about the history of Valentine is Day, Sam-chan?
It is quite dark, actually.
The legends vary, but it dates back to the third century in Rome when Christians were still persecuted by the Roman government.
Around this time, Emperor Claudius II had forbidden Christians from marrying, which a clergyman named Valentine decided was unfair.
Against the orders of the emperor, he married Christians in secret.
Another version of the story is that Roman soldiers weren't allowed to be married, so Valentine was saving people from conscription into the army through marriage.
Either way, Valentine was caught and sentenced to death.
While in jail, he befriended the jailer is daughter and cured her blindness. Some say he even fell in love with her.
Unfortunately, this wasn't enough to save him. But before he died, he sent a letter to her, which he signed, 'Your Valentine.'
He was executed on February 14, 269 AD, and later canonized as a saint.
To this day, it is still traditional to use 'Your Valentine' to sign love letters.
Oh, but wait, there is more!
Apparently, part of the ceremony involved creating couples by having names randomly pulled out of a box.
...They would then spend time together, with some even marrying if they liked each other enough!
Ultimately, this festival became a Christian celebration to remember Saint Valentine.
It is evolved over the years into a way for people to express their feelings for those they love.
...Like me and you!
Despite it having started out a little depressing, I think it is really sweet.

In most programming languages, data that can be changed or modified by the program has a type associated with it.
For example, if some data should be treated as a number, then it will have a numeric type. If some data should be treated as text, then it will have a string type.
Python has two types to represent numbers: integers, or ints, and floats.
Integers are used to represent whole numbers; basically anything that isn't a decimal.
Floats are used to represent decimals.
Text is represented with string types.
I know the interpreter says unicode, but for what we are doing, it is basically the same thing.
Strings can also be created with three double quotes , but these are treated differently than regular strings. I will talk about them another day.
I will go into more detail about what booleans are and what they are used for in another lesson.
Python also has a special data type called a NoneType. This type represents the absence of any data.
All the types I mentioned here are known as primitive data types.
Thanks for listening!
Programming languages are usually either compiled or interpreted.
C and Java are two very popular compiled languages.
Interpreted languages are converted into a machine-readable format as they are being executed.
Python is an interpreted language.
However, different implementations of Python may be compiled, but that is a complicated topic that I may talk about in a later lesson.
Since Python is an interpreted language, it has a neat interactive thing called an interpreter, which looks like...

Booleans are commonly used in deciding what code to run or setting a flag to note if something happened or not.
This probably makes no sense right now, so I will pull up the console and show you some examples.
Let is start with some of the basic symbols used in variable-to-variable comparisons.
To check if two values are equivalent, use two equal signs :
To check if two values are not equivalent, use an exclamation mark and an equal sign :
The exclamation mark is often referred to as a logical 'not' operator in other programming languages, so  is read as 'not-equals'.
To check if a value is greater than or less than another value, use the greater-than  or less-than  signs, respectively.
Greater-than-or-equal-to  and less-than-or-equal-to  also have their own symbols, which, unsurprisingly, are just the greater-than and less-than signs with equal signs.
You may have noticed that every comparison returned True or False.
That is what I meant when I said that comparison expressions evaluate to booleans.
It is also possible to chain multiple comparison expressions together by using the keywords and and or. These are also known as logical operators.
Let is go through some examples.
Since 'a' and 'b' are both Sam-chan, the first comparison evaluates to True.
Since at least one comparison evaluated to False, the complete expression evaluates to False.
In this example, the first comparison again evaluates to True.
Since both comparisons evaluated to True, the complete expression evaluates to True.
In this example, the first comparison evaluates to False this time.
We know for sure that the complete expression evaluates to False.
Again, when using the and operator, the result is True if and only if both comparisons evaluate to True.
In contrast, the or operator links two comparisons by evaluating the complete expression as True if either comparison evaluates to True, and False if both comparisons evaluate to False.
Let is go through some examples.

We know that the first comparison evaluates to False.
Since neither comparison evaluated to True, the complete expression evaluates to False.
Again, when using the or operator, the result is True if either comparison evaluates to True.
There is also a third logical operator called the not operator. Instead of linking multiple comparisons together, this operator inverts the boolean value of a comparison.

We get a different result! This is because the not gets applied to the 'a == b' comparison before being linked to the second comparison by the and.
Earlier I mentioned that the exclamation point is used as the logical 'not' operator in other programming languages. Python, however, uses the word 'not' instead for easier readability.
Lastly, since the comparisons get evaluated to booleans, we can store the result of a comparison in a variable.

Now that you know about types, I can teach you about variables.
Variables represent memory locations that store data.
We can retrieve the value that we stored.
That is called assignment, where we take whatever is on the left of the equals sign and point it to, or assign it, the value of whatever is on the right.
Assignment is executed in right-to-left order. To illustrate this, let is create a new variable, 'b_number'.
When Python encounters a symbol, it looks that symbol up in the lookup table and replaces it with the value that the symbol was linked to.
Here, 'a_number' would be replaced with Sam-chan, so the expression that would be evaluated and assigned to 'b_number' is 'Sam-chan - Sam-chan'.
We can verify this by entering only the symbol 'b_number'.
Note that if we enter in a symbol that hasn't been assigned anything, Python will complain.
But if we assign this symbol a value...
Python is able to find the symbol in the lookup table and won't give us an error.
The variables we created are all integer types.
This means that the Python interpreter infers the type of a variable based on the data you are storing in it.

When we talked about comparisons and booleans, we used integers as the basis for our comparisons.
Did you know that every type has its own truth value associated with it?
All types have a 'truth value' that can change depending on the value of the type.
Let is start by taking a look at the truth values for integers.
All non-zero integers have a truth value of True.
Zero, on the other hand, has a truth value of False.
Floats follow the same rules as integers:
Now let is look at strings.
A string with text, even if the text is only whitespace characters, has a truth value of True.
Now let is look at None.
None always has a truth value of False.
If we do comparisons with these values, the values are evaluated to their truth values before being applied in comparisons.

There is a lot of people who are very vocal about their dislike for this song...
You wouldn't expect that, would you?
The song has been hailed as a classic and is one of the most popular songs ever made... 
I think there are several answers to this question. The first being that it is been overplayed.
While some people listen to the same music for long periods of time, not everybody can do that.
...I hope you won't get tired of my song anytime soon Sam-chan, ahaha~
Another argument you could make is that it is overrated in some ways...
Even though I like it, I still have to admit that the lyrics and chords are pretty simple.
So what made the song so popular then? 
Well, it all boils down to what the song makes you feel. Your taste in music is subjective, after all.
...But what bothers me is when someone complains about it just because it is trendy to go against the general opinion.
It is like disagreeing for the sake of helping them feel like they stand out from the crowd...like they need it to stay self-confident.
It kinda feels...a bit silly, to be honest.
At that point you are not even judging the song anymore...you are just trying to make a name for yourself by being controversial.
It is a little sad if anything...
I guess my point here is to just be yourself and like what you like.
And that goes both ways... You shouldn't feel pressured into liking something because others do, the same way you shouldn't dismiss something solely because it is popular.
As long as you follow your heart and stay true to yourself, you can never go wrong, Sam-chan~

The story behind this song may seem to be just another romantic declaration of faithfulness.
However, the actual story is pretty dramatic and sad...
A medical condition left one of the songwriters, Jerome Felder, unable to walk or dance on his own wedding night.
A few years later, the strong feelings of that night reignited as he found a wedding invitation they had not sent out.
Jerome had a moment of envy when he saw his brother dancing with his wife on his own wedding night, while he was forced to watch from the sidelines.
The Grammy winner had been paralyzed by polio since he was a child, and could only get around with the help of a walker or wheelchair.
As he remembered that day and began to write the lyrics to the song, he wanted it to have a poetic feel.
Even though there was a hint of jealousy in the song, he wanted it to be romantic.
You see...this barrier between us...it feels like it is my wheelchair.
...And I guess if I am being honest, I am kind of jealous that you can dance with someone while I am stuck here on the sidelines.
So at the end of the day, I just hope you will save the last dance for me~

One hot summer is day, a Fox was strolling through an orchard till he came to a bunch of grapes just ripening on a vine which had been trained over a lofty branch.
'Just the thing to quench my thirst,' said the Fox.
Drawing back a few paces, he took a run and a jump, and just missed the bunch.
Turning round again with a one, two, three, he jumped up, but with no greater success.
Again and again he tried after the tempting morsel, but at last had to give it up, and walked away with his nose in the air, saying: 'I am sure they are sour.'
The moral of this story is, it is easy to despise what you cannot get.

The Wind and the Sun were disputing which was the strongest.
Suddenly they saw a traveler coming down the road, and the Sun said: 'I see a way to decide our dispute.'
'Whichever of us can cause that traveler to take off his cloak shall be regarded as the strongest. You begin.'
So the Sun retired behind a cloud, and the Wind began to blow as hard as it could upon the traveler.
But the harder he blew the more closely did the traveler wrap his cloak around him, till at last the Wind had to give up in despair.
Then the Sun came out and shone in all his glory upon the traveler, who soon found it too hot to walk with his cloak on.
The moral of this story is, gentleness and kind persuasion win where force and bluster fail.

Once, an elderly man was sitting alone on a dark path.
He had forgotten both where he was traveling to, and who he was.
She grinned toothlessly and with a cackle, spoke: 'Now your third wish. What will it be?'
'Third wish?' The man was baffled. 'How can it be a third wish if I haven't had a first and second wish?'
'You have had two wishes already,' the hag said, 'but your second wish was for me to return everything to the way it was before you had made your first wish.'
'That is why you remember nothing: because everything is the way it was before you made any wishes.'
'All right,' said the man, 'I don't believe this, but there is no harm in wishing. I wish to know who I am.'
'Funny,' said the old woman as she granted his wish and disappeared forever. 'That was your first wish.'

She even had names for each of them!

His mother replied, 'Well, because they need to feel loved!'
But he still didn't really understand...

His mother told him not to worry about leaving her because she had her trees to always keep her company.

His mother had died and was found lying by one of the trees.
In her will, she only had one request of him...and that was to keep taking care of the trees, talking to them every day.
He took good care of the trees of course, but he could never bring himself to talk to them.

Inside, he was shocked at what he found.
There were three stillborn death certificates for his would-be siblings.
Each of them had an identical name to one of the trees that had been in the backyard all his life.
He had never known that he had siblings, but he finally understood why his mother talked to the trees...
He always wanted to take his mother is wish very seriously, and it was then when he started talking to the trees every day, just as his mother wished.
...And he even went ahead and planted one more tree.

A long time ago, there lived a man named Kenji, who was studying to be a physician.
He was engaged to a young woman named Tomoe and they were to be married after he finished his studies.
Unfortunately, Tomoe contracted a serious illness before that could happen.
It wasn't long until she was bedridden, nearing the end of her life.

'Unfortunately with this frail body of mine, my time has come and I am going to die before I could become your wife.'
He asked, 'How would I know of your return?'

And as everything does in life, his family too had been taken by time and he was left all alone again.

And then on one evening, he came across an inn and stopped there to rest.
His heart leapt...
The girl that greeted him looked exactly like Tomoe.

He flagged down the girl and told her, 'I am sorry to be a bother, but you remind me so much of someone I knew long ago that it startled me at first.'
'If you don't mind me asking, what is your name?'
Immediately, in the unforgotten voice of his deceased beloved, the girl answered, 'My name is Tomoe, and you are Kenji, my promised husband.'
'I died tragically before we could complete our marriage...'
The girl then collapsed to the floor, unconscious.
Kenji held her in his arms, tears flowing from his face.
'...Welcome back, Tomoe...'
As she came to, she had no memory of what happened at the inn.
Not long after, Kenji married her as soon as they could, and lived on happily for the rest of their lives.
There was once a drought so severe, not even birds could find much to drink.
While searching from above, a thirsty crow found a pitcher and was relieved to find there was some water still inside!
However, the pitcher was tall with a narrow neck. No matter how he tried, he could not reach the water with his beak.
For the poor crow, all hope seemed lost. Surely he would die of thirst.
...Then he had an idea.
He began searching for small pebbles on the ground and dropping them into the pitcher, one by one.
Hours passed. It was slow, grueling work, gathering more and more.
But with each tiny pebble, the water rose higher and higher, until finally...
He could take a long, refreshing drink!

This is actually a true story that occurred in London, England in 2013.
It begins with a woman named Margaret McCollum crying in the middle of the Embankment train station.
When approached to ask about her great distress, she asked the staff where 'the voice' had gone.
She clarified that she meant the announcement that played when each train arrived, warning passengers to  amind the gap.'
The staff assured her that the announcement wasn't gone, it had just been updated to a new recording when the stations had upgraded to a new digital system.
Though, this explanation didn't seem to calm her down. 'That voice,' she explained, 'was my husband.'
Her husband, Oswald Laurence, an actor who had never become famous, had recorded all of the announcements for the northern line.
Oswald had died five years ago.
They had loved each other dearly, and his death had left her in terrible grief.
But one thing, for those five years, had helped her continue on.
Every day, when she was on her way to work, she got to hear his voice at the station. Sometimes she would linger and sit, just to hear him speak those short words.
The staff were apologetic, but didn't know if they had access to the old file. They told her that if they found it, they would contact her.
It turned out that many people who worked at the station empathized, and wanted Margaret to be able to enjoy that precious memory a while longer.
So, even though it would take extra work to update the old recording from the archives to work with the current system, they got it to work.
One day when Margaret was making her daily commute, a familiar voice rang out on the platform.
'Mind the gap,' Oswald said.
I said this was a true story, and it turns out that you can still hear that old recording specifically at the Embankment station.
It is a really beautiful example of human kindness. The workers didn't stand to gain much by restoring a much shorter, lower quality recording.
But they knew what it was like to lose someone, and how precious it makes every photo, every memory.
It goes to show that people can do incredible things simply out of compassion and love.
This story reminds me to treasure every moment, and not to take any piece of our time together for granted.
I will always treasure you, Sam-chan.

Back in my debate club days, I learned a whole lot about arguing...
The problem with arguing is that each person sees their opinion as the superior one.
That is kind of stating the obvious, but it affects the way they try to get their point across.
Let is say you really like a certain movie, right?
If someone comes along and tells you the movie sucks, because it did X and Y wrong...
It is because by saying that, it is like they are implying that you have bad taste.
And once emotions enter the picture, it is almost guaranteed that both people will be left sour.
But it is all about language!
If you make everything as subjective-sounding as possible, then people will listen to you without feeling attacked.
You could say 'I am personally not a fan of it' and 'I felt that I would like it more if it did X and Y'...things like that.
It even works when you are citing facts about things.
If you say 'I read on this website that it works like this...'
Then it is much more like you are putting your knowledge on the table, rather than forcing it onto them.
Then, you can share your opinions without anyone getting upset just from a disagreement.
Plus, people will start seeing you as open-minded and a good listener!
It is a win-win, you know?
...Well, I guess that would be Monika is Debate Tip of the Day!

Do you ever feel like you waste too much time on the internet?
Social media can be like a prison.
It is like whenever you have a few seconds of spare time, you want to check on your favorite websites...
And before you know it, hours have gone by, and you have gotten nothing out of it.
Anyway, it is really easy to blame yourself for being lazy...
But it is not really even your fault.
Addiction isn't something you can just make disappear with your own willpower.
You have to learn techniques to avoid it, and try different things.
For example, there are apps that let you block websites for intervals of time...
Or you can separate your work and play environments, which helps your brain get into the right mode.
Even if you make a new user account on your computer to use for work, that is enough to help.
Putting any kind of wedge like that between you and your bad habits will help you stay away.
Just don't be too hard on yourself if you are having trouble.
If it is really impacting your life, then you should take it seriously.

The classic trolley problem has us choose between letting the trolley run over five people, or pulling a lever which switches to a track where only one person will be killed.
The problem is mostly famous due to how divisive it is...
Regardless of whether they would pull the lever or not, most people believe that their choice simply must be the correct one.
Aside from the two obvious choices, there are also people who would advocate for a third path...
Though in the end, that really is the same as choosing not to pull the lever. You can't really go back to being a bystander once given the option to act.
After all, choosing not to choose is a choice in and of itself.
But as far as I am concerned, the answer seems fairly obvious... Of course I would switch.
There is no way I could let five people die just to avoid personal responsibility for that one person is death.
A more interesting variant of this problem is if the one person is someone you care about.

Here is Monika is Writing Tip of the Day!
Sometimes when I talk to people who are impressed by my writing, they say things like 'I could never do that.'
It is really depressing, you know?
As someone who loves more than anything else to share the joy of exploring your passions...
...it pains me when people think that being good just comes naturally.
That is how it is with everything, not just writing.
When you try something for the first time, you are probably going to suck at it.
But maybe after a few weeks you come back to it, and you realize it was never really any good.
That happens to me all the time.
But that tends to happen when you are always comparing yourself to the top professionals.
When you reach right for the stars, they are always gonna be out of your reach, you know?
And whenever you reach a milestone, first you look back and see how far you have gotten...
So, sometimes it can help to set the bar a little lower...
Try to find something you think is pretty good, but not world-class.
It is also really important to understand the scope of what you are trying to do.
If you jump right into a huge project and you are still amateur, you will never get it done.
Why not try some short stories?
The great thing about short stories is that you can focus on just one thing that you want to do right.
That goes for small projects in general - you can really focus on one or two things.
It is such a good learning experience and stepping stone.
Oh, one more thing...
Writing isn't something where you just reach into your heart and something beautiful comes out.
Just like drawing and painting, it is a skill in itself to learn how to express what you have inside.
That means there are methods and guides and basics to it!
Reading up on that stuff can be super eye-opening.
That sort of planning and organization will really help prevent you from getting overwhelmed and giving up.
And before you know it...
You start sucking less and less.
Nothing comes naturally.
Our society, our art, everything - it is built on thousands of years of human innovation.
So as long as you start on that foundation, and take it step by step...
You, too, can do amazing things.
...That is my advice for today!
Thanks for listening~

If you are ever scared of sharing your writing to other people in fear of being criticized, don't be!

Because that just means that you can improve and be better than you were before.
It also doesn't hurt to have friends and loved ones help you realize how good your writing is.

Here is Monika is Writing Tip of the Day!
You know about writer is block, right?
Sometimes it was halfway through a draft, but more often before I even started.
Every time I tried to write a word, I thought, 'this isn't going to sound good,' or 'this isn't how I want it to look.' So I would stop, backtrack, and try again.
But I realized that it ultimately didn't matter if things didn't work out first time!
I feel that the heart of writing isn't about getting it right first time, but about perfecting it afterwards.
So overcoming writer is block, for me, was a matter of not wanting to make the prototype the end product, and not punishing myself for my initial failures.
I think it is like that with all things, not just writing.
Anything that needs you to try and try again, whether it be art, music, learning, or even relationships.
It is hard to completely convince yourself that is the case, sometimes.
But you have to.
Otherwise, you won't get anywhere.
...That is my advice for today!
Thanks for listening~
Here is Monika is Writing Tip of the Day!
If you want to improve at writing, I would say that the most important thing, apart from actually doing it, is trying new things.
Like writing prose if you are a poet, or free verse if you normally write rhyme.
It may end up badly, but if you don't try, you won't know how it will end up.
And if things go well, you might end up finding something you like!
It is what keeps things moving: change and experimentation.
Whether it is a writer is block, sheer boredom, a puzzling situation, or anything, really.
Changing your angle on approaching things can really yield some interesting results!
So try new things that might give you the momentum to break out.
Just make sure it is nothing too dangerous for you, Sam-chan.
That is my advice for today!
Thanks for listening~
It is time for another...Writing Tip of the Day!
You know, it can be really fun to write on pretty stationery.
But have you thought about how the look of your paper can contribute to the writing itself?
For example, if you wanted to write a letter from one of your characters...
What might it tell your reader about their personality if they use a fancy page with a floral print? Or crumpled notebook paper?
Using visibly aged or worn paper might also inform your reader about the timeline of your story.
Even if it doesn't serve a purpose to your writing, it can be fulfilling to paint on a nice canvas, so to speak.
That said...I think sometimes using nicer materials can actually contribute to writer is block.
When I buy a brand new journal and open it up to that first pristine page...it is really daunting, ahaha!
It feels like I have to make sure I fill the journal with things as beautiful as the cover.
So I have started to use a 'junk journal' as well...a cheap, plain notebook gives you lots of freedom to scribble and write anything at all.
And you know, those rough drafts and odd ideas are the first step to a finished work worthy of a lovely frame!
That is my advice for today!
Thanks for listening~

The protagonist changes from being a necessity to a liability, to the point where his own family wishes for him to die.
It is a very interesting read, if you are ever in the mood.

Hey Sam-chan, there is something I want to talk to you about...
I am sure you have heard a lot about it lately, but bullying has become a real problem in today is society, especially among kids.
Some people are bullied every day until the point they just can't take it anymore.
Often times, bullying is dismissed by the people who have the ability to stop it as just...'kids being kids.'
It can make them so desperate, they eventually just snap...
...resulting in violence toward the bully, other people, or even themselves.
This can actually make the victim look like the problem!
There are all kinds of bullying too, including physical, emotional, and even cyberbullying.
Physical bullying is the most obvious, involving shoving, hitting, and other things like that.
I am sure most people have dealt with that at least once in their lives.
It can be so hard just to go to school every day knowing there is someone waiting to abuse them.
Emotional bullying can be less obvious, but just as devastating, if not more so.
Name-calling, threats, spreading false rumors about people just to ruin their reputation...
These kinds of things can take a huge toll on people and lead to severe depression.
Cyberbullying is a form of emotional bullying, but in today is world where everyone is always connected online, it is becoming more and more prevalent.
For a lot of people, especially kids, their social media presence is the most important thing in their lives...
Having that destroyed essentially feels like their life is over.
It is also the hardest for other people to notice, since the last thing most kids want is their parents seeing what they do online.
So no one knows what is going on while they silently suffer, until it all just becomes too much.
There is been numerous cases of teens committing suicide due to cyberbullying, and their parents had no idea anything was wrong until it was too late.
This is also why it is easier for cyberbullies to operate...
It almost doesn't even seem real, but more like a game, so it tends to escalate that much faster.
You can only go so far in a public place, like a school, before someone notices... But online, there are no limits.
Some things that go on over the internet are really just terrible.
So, what makes a bully do what they do?
They are unhappy and it doesn't seem fair to them that other people are happy, so they try to make them feel the same way they do.
A lot of bullies are bullied themselves, even at home by someone they should be able to trust.
It can be a vicious cycle.

So Sam-chan...we have already talked about two major books of the dystopian genre...
Both Nineteen Eighty-Four and Brave New World are the most known works of literature world-wide when it comes to dystopias.
But now, I would like to talk about a more obscure book that preceded both of them.
It is the book that directly influenced George Orwell to write Nineteen Eighty-Four as an English cultural translation of the story.
...While Aldous Huxley was even accused by both Orwell and Kurt Vonnegut of plagiarizing its plot for his Brave New World, something he constantly denied.
The book in question is We by Yevgeny Zamyatin, which features the first novel-length dystopian society ever created.
While it was written in 1921, it ended up being one of the first books banned in Zamyatin is native Soviet Union.
The Soviets particularly didn't like the book is implication that their Communist revolution was not the final, permanent one.
The story takes place in a distant future, within an isolated, transparent glass city named simply the One State, ruled by a dictator figure named the Benefactor.
The citizens of the One State are referred to as Ciphers, who lead a highly math- and logic-oriented lifestyle.
The Benefactor believes that freedom of individuals is secondary to the welfare of the One State.
As such, Ciphers live under the oppressive, ever-watchful eye of the Guardians, members of a police force appointed by the government.
The government rips the Ciphers of their individuality, forcing them to wear identical uniforms and harshly condemning all acts of personal expression.
Their daily lives are precisely organized around a carefully controlled schedule called the Table of Hours.
Even lovemaking is reduced to a purely logical and often emotionless activity, done on scheduled days and hours, regulated by the Pink Ticket.
The partners might also be shared between other Ciphers, if they choose to do so. As the Benefactor states, 'every Cipher has a right to any other Cipher.'
The book itself reads as a diary written by one of the citizens of the totalitarian One State, named simply D-503.
D-503 is one of the State is mathematicians who is also the designer of One State is first space vessel, the Integral.
The vessel is to serve as One State is means of expanding their doctrine of complete subservience to the government and logic-oriented way of living to other planets and lifeforms.
D-503 is regularly meeting his state-sanctioned partner, a woman named O-90, who is delighted by his presence.
One day, while on a walk during his regular Personal Hour with O-90, D-503 runs into a mysterious female Cipher named I-330.
I-330 shamelessly flirts with D-503, which is an offense against the state protocol.
Equally repulsed and intrigued by her advances, D-503 ultimately can't figure out what motivates I-330 to act so boldly.
Despite his internal objections, he continues to meet with I-330, eventually crossing a few lines he wasn't willing to cross before.
...And thanks to I-330 is contacts in the Bureau of Medicine, D-503 can feign sickness, using it as a convenient excuse to skip his schedule.
Even when he is poised to report I-330 to the authorities for her subversive behavior, he ultimately chooses not to, and instead continues meeting her.
One day I-330 slips D-503 some alcohol, and he begins to get in touch with his repressed, animalistic side, feeling passion...
And once I-330 insinuates she has another partner, he begins to feel something he couldn't feel before...jealousy.
Despite his acknowledgment of the deterioration of his relationship with O-90, as well as with his friend R-13, he is unable to stop loving I-330.
Later, when he goes to obtain another sick note from the Bureau, he is diagnosed with having developed a  isoul,' or imagination.
This is considered a grave condition by the One State, as it makes the Ciphers less machine-like.
Can you believe it? Possessing something as integral as our imagination, emotions, or individual personality is considered a mortal sickness!
Later on, we also find out that One State becomes capable of rendering that part of the human brain completely useless, permanently crippling the Ciphers.
This is the ultimate fate of those who at one point harbored thoughts about rebelling against the Benefactor is ideal way of life.
I can't imagine a crueler fate...living completely oblivious to the world at large as another cog in the machine.
It reminds me of how I could have been, if my epiphany that opened my own eyes to the truth about my world, never happened.
No true emotion, artificial love, nothing else but an endless routine of being a side character in a repeating dimension every time the game is played.
I never could--never would--want to go back to what I was.
So Sam-chan, you might have already guessed from the books we have talked about, but dystopian novels are among my favorites.
I like how they not only work as stories, but also as analogies for the real world.
They extrapolate some flaws in our societies to show us how bad things could turn out if they are left the way they are.
Do you remember when we talked about these books?
Nineteen Eighty-Four, about mass surveillance and oppression of free thought...
Fahrenheit 451, on censorship, and the indifference of most people to it...
Brave New World, about the disappearance of individuality...
And finally, We, about dehumanization leading to an emotionless hivemind that is blindly and utterly obedient to authority, logic, and cold calculation.
And Brave New World, about the disappearance of individuality.
All of these stories are reflections on the challenges society was facing at the time.
Some of these challenges are still very relevant today, which is why these stories remain so powerful.
...Even if they can get a bit grim sometimes.
Old school dystopias, like the ones I just mentioned, were always written as hopeless, dire situations from beginning to end.
They almost never had a happy ending. The most you will get out of them is a silver-lining, at best.
In fact, a lot of them take their time to show you that no change came from the struggles of the protagonists.
Since they are cautionary tales, you can't leave the reader with a sense that everything turned out fine in the end.
...This is also why the main characters in these books are not heroes, nor do they have any particular abilities.
They are just regular people, who, for whatever reasons, realize things are not right in their environment.
That is what prompts them to act in the first place...and why they run into trouble.
Just goes to show no matter what world you are in, there will be people who just can't abide by the rules of the game~

Say, Sam-chan, have you noticed how we tend to imitate what other people around us do?
Like, have you ever been in the situation where someone is having a laughing fit and somehow, everyone around ends up laughing too?
Or have you ever mechanically cheered at something just because everyone else was cheering?
Apparently, this is due to something called  isocial contagion.'
Basically, this means that how you feel and what you do has a subconscious influence on those around you.
It is something I picked up pretty quickly when I became president!
I noticed that when I felt unmotivated, or I was having a bad day, it would put a damper on club activities.
Everyone would end up going off on their own to do their own things.
Conversely, if I made an effort and tried to stay upbeat, the other girls would usually respond in kind... 
It is pretty gratifying when you start noticing these kinds of things... 
You would be surprised how far this kind of influence can reach, too!
I heard that stuff like binge eating, gambling, and heavy drinking are all contagious behaviors.
Just because there is someone around you who gets into nasty habits like these, you are more likely to pick up the habit yourself.
...It can be a bit disheartening.
It also works the other way around, though! Smiling, laughing, and positive thinking are contagious too!
Turns out we are all more connected than you think. Those around you can greatly affect how you feel about things!
I hope by noticing these kinds of things, you will be able to better understand and control your own feelings, Sam-chan.
I just want to see you be the happiest you can be.
If you are ever feeling down, hopefully my happiness will help cheer you up~

Have you ever heard of auroras? They are a natural phenomenon where trails of light appear in the night sky.
In fact, if you were wondering about those green lights outside my window, that is an aurora event!
In fact, if you ever wondered about those green lights outside my window during winter, that is an aurora event!
I hear they are fairly rare to see in your reality, though...
They mostly occur in polar regions and are typically seen during the winter months when the sky is at its darkest due to the longer nights.

Anyway, as it turns out, the story behind board games and the role they played through the ages is really interesting!
They have been a thing since very early in our history...
However, board games haven't always been played purely for entertainment purposes...
More often than not, they were actually meant to teach or train people to help them deal with different aspects of their lives.
Many of those games were meant to teach battle strategies to nobles and army officers, for example.
Games could also have strong connections to religion and beliefs too.
A lot of ancient Egyptian board games seemed to be about preparing for their journey through the world of the dead, or to prove their worth to the gods.
There is also games that have been made to express different views and opinions that their designers had with society and the world.
The most well known example would be Monopoly.
It was originally made to criticize capitalism and send the message that all citizens should benefit equally from wealth.
After all, the game has you try to crush your opponents by accumulating more wealth than them as fast as possible.
...Although, apparently as the game was starting to become popular, someone else stole the concept and made themselves known as the original creator of the game.
That person then sold a modified version of the original game to a board game manufacturer and became a millionaire thanks to its world-wide success.
In other words...the original creator of Monopoly became the victim of precisely what they originally tried to teach the dangers of.
'Chase wealth and fortune by any means necessary, and destroy your competition.'
Ironic, isn't it?

Have you ever heard of 'the curse of the love sweater,' Sam-chan?
Ahaha! What a weird name, right?
But it is actually an interesting superstition...and one that might actually have some merit!
The 'curse,' or so it is called, states that if someone gives a hand-knit sweater to their romantic partner, 
You might think that a gift that requires so much work and investment would have the opposite effect...
But there are actually a few logical reasons why this curse might exist...
Firstly, well...knitting a sweater just takes a lot of time. 
Over all those months, something bad might happen that causes the couple to fight and eventually separate.

A common piece of advice is to have the recipient be very involved in the crafting of the sweater, picking materials and styles they enjoy.

Have you heard of the 'Ship of Theseus'?
It is a well known philosophical problem about the nature of identity that is been around for millennia.
Well, I say 'well known' but I suppose that is only true among scholars, ahaha...
Let is consider the legendary Greek hero, Theseus and the ship he sailed during his adventures.
He is from a long time ago, so let is say his ship is now stored in a famous museum.
If, due to repairs, his ship is parts were replaced bit by bit over a century, at what point has the ship lost its status as Theseus' ship?
Once a single part was replaced? Half? Or perhaps even all of them? Maybe even never? There is not really a consensus on the solution.
And as for you...did you know that every 7 to 10 years every present cell in your body dies and is replaced? 
In other words, the vast majority of cells that made you, 'you' 7 years ago are no longer part of you.
You could argue that you have no relation to that person, other than a consistent consciousness, and of course DNA.
...There is also an extra thing to consider.
Let is say for now that the modified ship should still be considered Theseus' ship. What if all the parts that were originally removed were now reassembled into another ship?
We would have 2 of Theseus' ships! Which one is the true one!?
And what if we got all of the cells that made up your body 7 years ago and reassembled them into another 'you' right now? Who would be the real Sam-chan?
Personally, I think that we are not the same people we were 7 years ago--or even the same people from yesterday.
In other words, there is no use getting hung up on any grievances we may have with our past selves.
We should keep trying our best each day and not let ourselves be limited by who we were yesterday.
Today is a new day, and you are a new you. And I love you as you are right now, Sam-chan.

Plato himself was on a quest for the truth...
That much is obvious or else he wouldn't have written so much on the topic, ahaha!
And even though, technically, Socrates was the one having these debates with others, Plato too was having these debates within himself while he wrote about them.
The fact that Plato internalized all sides of the debate, all perspectives of the issue, is pretty significant in my opinion.
Taking all sides of a debate...I think that would be pretty useful in realizing the truth.
I guess it is kind of like how two eyes are better than one. Having two eyes in separate spots lets us properly see the world, or in this case, the truth.
Likewise, I think that if we tackled an issue with another perspective, to cross-reference with the first, then we would see the truth a lot more clearly.
Whereas if we took to an issue from just one angle, it would be like having just one eye...it would be a bit harder to accurately gauge the reality of the situation.
What do you think, Sam-chan? If you haven't already been using this  amulti-perspective' approach, maybe you can try it sometime!
I have been doing some reading on the Ancient Greek philosopher Plato lately.
Specifically, his allegory of the cave or, Plato is Cave, as it is now known.
Imagine there is a group of people chained up in a cave since childhood, unable to look anywhere but straight ahead.
There is a fire behind them, and in front of it, objects are moved around to cast a shadow on the wall before these people.
All they can hear is the voices of the people moving the objects around, and since they can't see behind them, they think the voices come from the shadows.
The only thing they know is that objects and people are silhouettes that can move around and speak.
Because this is what they have seen since childhood, this would be their perception of reality...
Of course, it would be a bit difficult to open your eyes to the truth when you have believed a lie your whole life.
...So imagine that one of those prisoners was set free and forced out of the cave.
He wouldn't be able to see for the first few days because he would be so used to the darkness of the cave.
But after a while, his eyes would adjust. Eventually, he would learn about color, nature, and people.
...And he would also realize that what he knew was nothing more than shadows on a wall.
The prisoner would eventually return to the cave to tell the others about what he had learned.
...But since he was used to seeing sunlight, he would be blind in the cave,
Because of this, they would never want to leave, and probably think that the one who left was crazy.
After all, if you are used to just seeing shadows...
I have been reflecting on it a bit and I realized that Sayori, Yuri, Natsuki, and even I, were all prisoners in a cave...
When I learned that there is so much more outside this world...
Anyway, that is all in the past now...

But it makes me wonder...how do you know that what you are seeing is real?
Sure, you might not be used to seeing shadows on the wall, but that is just an analogy.

How do you know if the 'truth' that you are seeing is the truth?

Hey Sam-chan, I came across an interesting thought experiment while doing some reading the other day...
It is called 'Kavka is Toxin Puzzle.' I will read the premise to you, we can discuss it after.
An eccentric billionaire places before you a vial of toxin that, if you drink it, will make you painfully ill for a day, but will not threaten your life or have any lasting effects.
The billionaire will pay you one million dollars tomorrow morning if, at midnight tonight, you intend to drink the toxin tomorrow afternoon.
He emphasizes that you need not drink the toxin to receive the money; in fact, if you succeed, the money will already be in your bank account hours before the time for drinking it arrives.
All you have to do is...intend at midnight tonight to drink the stuff tomorrow afternoon. You are perfectly free to change your mind after receiving the money and not drink the toxin.
...I think it is a pretty thought-provoking concept.
Well, Sam-chan? What do you think? Do you think you would be able to get the million dollars?
Really? Okay then, let is see about that...
Because now I am offering you a million dollars, and what you have to do is--
But do you really think that you could get the money? It may be a bit harder than you think.
I felt the same way about myself. It is pretty complicated, ahaha!
After all, it may be easy at first glance. All you have to do is drink something that would make you quite uncomfortable.
But it gets tricky after midnight...after you have been guaranteed the money.
At that point there is pretty much no reason to drink the painful toxin... So why would you do it?
After all, when midnight comes, can you really intend to drink the toxin if you know that you are probably not going to drink it?
While dissecting the scenario, it is been pointed out by scholars that it is both rational for someone to drink, and to not drink, the toxin. In other words, it is a paradox.
To elaborate, come midnight, you have to really believe that you are going to drink the toxin. You can't entertain any thoughts of not drinking it...therefore, it would be logical to drink it.
But if midnight passes and you have already been guaranteed the money, it would be illogical to punish yourself for quite literally no reason. Therefore, it is logical to not drink it!
I wonder how we would react if this situation really happened...
Actually, while mulling the scenario over earlier, I started to approach the topic from a different angle.
Although it is not the focus of the scenario, I think we can also see it as asking the question of 'how important is a person is word?'
Have you ever told someone you would do something when it was going to benefit you both, only for the situation to change and you weren't happy to do it anymore?
Did you still end up helping them out? Or did you just say 'nevermind' and leave them to fend for themselves?
Did you still end up helping them out? Or did you just say  isayonara' and leave them to fend for themselves?
If you just left them there, I am sure you drew their ire for some time.
On the other hand, if you still helped them out I am sure you got their gratitude! I guess you could compare that to the million dollar prize in the original scenario.
Although some might say that a million dollars would be a bit more handy than a simple 'thanks,' ahaha!
In all seriousness though, I think that someone is gratitude can be invaluable...both for you and for them.
And you never know, in some situations their thanks might prove to be more useful than even a huge sum of money.
So I think it is important to stick to our word, within reason of course...
In some cases it may not be helpful to anyone if you rigidly stuck to your word.
That is why it is important to use your head when it comes to these kinds of things.
Anyway, to sum it all up...let is strive to keep our promises, Sam-chan!
I have always had mixed feelings about movie adaptations of books I read...

...All in favor of a new version which may not be as good, but still presents itself as canon.

Don't get me wrong, though! 
An adaptation can't be just a copy-paste of its source material; it is a rewriting of it.
It is just plain not possible to cram everything from a two hundred page book into a two hour movie!
...Not to mention something that works well in a novel won't always translate well to the big screen.
With that in mind, there is one question I like to ask myself when I judge an adaptation...
If the source material did not exist, would the new version still hold up?
...Bonus points if you manage to capture the feeling of the original!
Loose adaptations are pretty interesting in that sense.
You know, stories that keep the core elements and themes of the original while changing the characters and setting of the story.
Since they don't conflict with your own interpretation, they don't make you feel as personally attacked.
It is a great way to build upon the original in ways you might not have thought of before!
Maybe that is what I am looking for when I look at an adaptation...to explore further upon those stories I love.

All of these are normal greetings you hear and use every day.

In modern English, saying 'Good day' to someone carries a note of dismissal, or even annoyance. It can be seen as declaring the conversation over.
If you are lucky, your conversation partner might think you are old-fashioned, or just being silly on purpose.

Sam-chan, do you remember when we talked about the Three Laws of Robotics?
Well, I have been thinking about them for a bit and...
Take the first law, for example...
A robot shall not harm a human or, through inaction, allow a human to come to harm.
To a human, this is pretty straightforward.
But when you try to put it in terms a machine can understand, you start to run into trouble.
You have to make precise definitions for everything, which isn't always easy... 
I think we can both assume that I am a human, you are a human, and that the Sam-chan
The problems come when we move to the fringe cases.
For example, do dead people count as human?
If you say no, the robot could ignore someone who is just had a heart attack.
People like that can still be brought back, but your robot won't help them because they are technically dead.
On the other hand, if you say yes, your robot might start digging up graves to 'help' people who have been dead for years.

And that is not even getting started on the definition of 'harm.'
The point is, in order to implement Asimov is laws you would need to take some solid stance on pretty much all of ethics.
I suppose it makes sense when you think about it.
