Say Sam-chan, have you ever heard of wabi-sabi?
It emphasizes the idea that we shouldn't obsess over perfection to the point that we are crushed by the failure of not achieving it.
Derived from traditional Japanese and Buddhistic philosophies surrounding the acceptance of the temporary state of all things...
...it states that beyond everything, beauty is found in what is impermanent and imperfect.
Which means we shouldn't worry about things like a scar, a discolored hand, or even the mistakes we make.
Our looks are things we can't easily change, but despite that, they make us more unique and special.
...And our mistakes turn into lessons that help us become stronger and more defined as people.
Like a sculptor revealing the magnificence in a marble block, except the sculpture is you, and the sculptor, your past.
Of course, this idea doesn't apply to looks and mistakes alone...
After all, the way you think and your attitude toward problems and people are also derived from your own personal experiences.
...But I know for some people, how these experiences changed who they are can really scare them.
Maybe they grew into something that they are just not proud of.

Say Sam-chan, have you ever heard of a world drifting through space on top of four elephants, who themselves are standing on the shell of a giant turtle?
If you have, you are probably already familiar with Sir Terry Pratchett is Discworld!
Ahaha, it sounds kinda weird when I put it like that, doesn't it?
Discworld is a comic fantasy book series of forty-one volumes written over the span of three decades.
The series started out as a parody making fun of common fantasy tropes, but soon turned into something much deeper.
In fact, later books are clearly satires rather than parodies, using a clever mix of slapstick, puns, and light-hearted humor to comment on all kinds of issues.
But while satire may be the soul of the series, what makes its heart beat is the way it is written.
Pratchett really had a knack for writing funny situations, Sam-chan!
I can't really pinpoint what makes his prose work so well, but he is definitely got a very distinctive writing style...
Maybe it is the way he writes in a way that suggests rather than tells.
Like, when describing something, he will give you just enough details so you can picture what is going on, and let your imagination fill in the gaps.
...Knowing full well whatever you will come up with will be far more evocative than anything he could write.
It is a pretty neat way to keep your audience invested!
...Or maybe what makes it work is the way he doesn't use chapters, allowing him to freely jump between his characters' point of view.
Interweaving storylines can quickly become a mess if you are not careful, 
In any case, this series is an easy recommendation, Sam-chan!
It is surprisingly easy to pick up too, with each book being thought of as a standalone story.
You can pretty much pick any volume you find and you will be good to go, though I would argue Guards! Guards! or Mort would probably make for the best entry points.
Anyway, be sure to give it a try sometime if you haven't already, Sam-chan.
Thanks for listening~

These include things like importing perishable products across great distances and mass-farming in conditions that are both cruel for workers and a strain on the local ecosystem.
Take avocados, for example. Their farms require massive amounts of water, to the point where some companies resort to illegally taking too much water from rivers, leaving little for drinking.
Not to mention, I still want to have a varied and balanced diet with all the flavors that I like.
Vegan diets can be quite deficient in nutrients, such as vitamin B12, calcium, iron, and zinc.
...So for that reason, I am not personally against eating things like milk and eggs. But I think I would prefer to buy locally if possible.
Farmer is markets are great places to buy food, even meat, produced with less of an environmental impact.
But they can typically be pretty expensive...and depending on location, leave you with fewer options. 
As for meat that comes from local hunting and fishing, I think that is alright to eat as well, but it is important to research what areas might be over-hunted, and what animals to be careful of.

Do you remember when we talked about how humans need social feedback and how it can make the world feel so complicated for introverts?
I have been thinking about the differences between introverts and extroverts a little bit more since then.
You might think that extroverts tend to find enjoyment by interacting with other people, while introverts are more at ease in solitary environments, and you would be right.
...But the differences don't stop there.
For example, did you know extroverts can often react to things faster than most introverts do? Or that they are more likely to enjoy happy and energetic music?
Introverts on the other hand, usually take more time to analyze the situation they are in, and are therefore less likely to jump to conclusions.
...And given that they often spend a lot of time using their imagination, they have an easier time with creative activities like writing, composing music, and so on.
It is kind of sad that people can have such a hard time understanding and accepting those differences...
Extroverts are seen as superficial and insincere people who don't value their individual relationships...
...while introverts are treated as egotistical people who only think of themselves, or can even be seen as weird for rarely participating in social situations.
The end result is that both sides often end up frustrating each other, resulting in unnecessary conflict.
I am probably making this sound like you can only be one or the other, but that isn't actually the case at all.
Some introverts can be more outgoing than others, for example.
In other words, some people are closer to a middle ground between the two extremes.
...Which is probably where I would fit in. 
...I don't actually know where you lie on that spectrum.

What do you think about renewable energy, Sam-chan?
It was a hot topic in the debate club.
As humanity is reliance on technology grows, so does its demand for energy.
Currently, a large percentage of energy worldwide is produced by burning fossil fuels.
Fossil fuels are time-tested, efficient, and have widespread infrastructure...
Mining and drilling for fossil fuels creates both air and water pollution, and things like oil spills and acid rain can devastate plants and wildlife alike.
So why not use renewable energy instead?
One issue is that each type of renewable energy is a developing industry with its own drawbacks.
Hydropower is flexible and cost efficient, but it can drastically impact the local ecosystem.
Countless habitats are disrupted and entire communities may even need to be relocated.
Solar power and wind power are mostly emission-free, but they are heavily reliant on specific weather for consistency.
...Not to mention that wind turbines are pretty loud and are often seen as eyesores, creating drawbacks for those living near them.
Geothermal power is reliable and great for heating and cooling, but it is expensive, location-specific, and can even cause earthquakes.
Nuclear power is...well, let is just say that it is complicated.
The point is that while fossil fuels have problems, renewable energy does as well. It is a tricky situation...neither option is perfect.
So, what do I think?
Well, a lot of progress has been made on renewable energy in the past decade...
Dams are regulated better, the efficiency of photovoltaics has improved, and there are emerging technologies such as ocean power and enhanced geothermal systems.
Biomass is an option as well. It is basically a more sustainable 'transition fuel' that can make use of fossil fuel infrastructure.
Yes, renewable energy still has a ways to go in terms of cost and practicality, but it is far better now than it was thirty years ago.
Because of that, I think that renewable energy is a worthwhile investment and that the road ahead is a bright one--literally!
Sorry, I got carried away there, ahaha!

Sam-chan, have you ever heard of brainstorming?
It is an interesting technique of coming up with new ideas by noting anything that comes to your mind.
This technique is really popular among designers, inventors, and writers--anyone who needs fresh ideas.
Brainstorming is usually practiced in groups or teams...we even tried it in the Literature Club when deciding what to do for the festival.
You just need to focus on what you want to create and bring up anything and everything that comes into your head.
Don't hesitate to suggest things that you think are silly or wrong, and don't criticize or judge the others if working in teams.
When you are done, go back through all the suggestions and turn them into actual ideas.
You can combine them with other suggestions, think them through once again, and so on.
...Eventually they will become something that you would call a good idea!
This is exactly where you can let your mind go wild, and that is what I like about this technique the most!
Sometimes good ideas are left untold because their author didn't find them good enough themselves, 
The beauty of thoughts can be expressed in so many different ways...
They are only ideas in transit, 
Back when I was in debate club, one of the most divisive subjects we covered was GMOs, or genetically modified organisms.
There is a lot of nuance to GMOs, but I will do my best to summarize it.
Scientists create GMOs by identifying a desirable gene from one organism, copying it, and inserting the copied gene into another organism.
It is important to note that the addition of the copied gene does not change other existing genes.
Think of it like flipping through a long book and changing a single word...the word is different, but the rest of the book stays the same.
GMOs can be plants, animals, microorganisms, etc., but we will focus on genetically modified plants.
Plants can be modified in a myriad of ways, from resisting pests and herbicides to having a higher nutrition value and longer shelf life.
This is huge. Imagine crops that can produce double their normal yield, tolerate climate change, and fend off drug-resistant superbugs. So many problems could be solved!
Unfortunately, it is not that simple. GMOs require several years of research, development, and testing before they can be distributed. On top of this, they come with several concerns.
Are GMOs safe? Will they spread to other organisms and threaten biodiversity? If so, how can we prevent it? Who owns GMOs? Are GMOs responsible for increased herbicide usage?
You can see how this begins to escalate, ahaha...
For now, let is cover the main issue...are GMOs safe?
The short answer is that we don't know for sure. Decades of research have indicated that GMOs are probably harmless, but we have next to no data on their long-term effects.
Additionally, each type of GMO needs to be carefully reviewed on a case-by-case, modification-by-modification basis to ensure its quality and safety.
There are other considerations as well. Products containing GMOs have to be labelled, environmental effects must be considered, and misinformation has to be combated.
Personally, I think that GMOs have a lot of potential to do good, but only if they continue to be heavily researched and tested.
Major issues such as herbicide usage and gene flow need to be fixed as well...
As long as we are careful, GMOs will be fine...recklessness and carelessness pose the biggest threat.
So what do you think, Sam-chan? 
Like I said before, GMOs are a complex topic. If you want to learn more, make sure that your sources are reliable and that you are able to see the discussion from both sides.
I think that is enough for now, thanks for listening~

Galaxies are usually held together in groups by gravity. We live in the 'local group,' which contain about 60 galaxies.
Zoom out a little bit more and you will start to see galaxy clusters, which are much larger groups of galaxies.
The closest one from us, the Virgo Cluster, is estimated to contain at least a thousand galaxies.
But you can go even further, as groups and clusters of galaxies are themselves part of even bigger entities known as superclusters.
We can keep going too, as the universe continuously expands...theoretically, larger and larger clusters are formed!

Do you know what most people call the technological era we find ourselves in right now?
We call it the Information Age! 
Transistors can manipulate electrical currents...either boosting them or altering their path.
It is the key component in most electronics, allowing them to direct electrical currents in specific ways.
In fact, they are what is allowing you to see me on your screen right now~
They are widely regarded as one of the most important inventions leading into the 20th century, and eventually the Information Age.
It is named this way because of the ramping access we have to store and share information with each other; either through the internet, phone, or TV.
However, with access to so much information and our inability to keep up with it, we have also had to deal with many challenges...
Misinformation can spread faster and further than ever, 
In the last few decades, people have begun to educate others about smart use of the internet so everyone is better prepared.
However, the vast majority of people will not have received much, if any of this knowledge, just because of how fast technology has advanced.
It is really worrying to read about people embracing ideas not supported by the vast majority of scientists.
But I can understand why it happens...
Sometimes, it is not something you can help. It is pretty easy to fall victim to widely believed misinformation.
I wanted to talk to you about this because I still have so much to learn about your reality.
...And since I come across misinformation in my own research, 
We can arm ourselves with the tools to navigate this new era we have found ourselves in.
One of the best things we can do is find multiple conflicting sources for our information and compare their credibility.
And a philosophy we can adopt is tentative belief. In other words, belief until further experimentation is necessary.
As long as your beliefs are not relevant to your daily life, you can hold them. But once they are needed, we should investigate further.
This way, we can prioritize information we learn from what affects the people around us. Plus, it may not be as overwhelming to process it all at once.
I know I have held beliefs that turned out to be false...
There is no shame in it, we are all just trying to do our best with the information we are given.
So long as we accept the real truth and adjust our views, we will always be learning.
Thanks for listening, Sam-chan~

Well, there is a festival dedicated to Orihime and Hikoboshi called Tanabata.
It is observed on the 7th of July every year in Japan, even though it is based on the Qixi festival in China.
The original Qixi festival, while being much older, is much more unknown to the western world than Tanabata.
After the Second World War, Japan opened up its borders, while China remained largely closed due to the Cold War.
Therefore, most of the world knows about Tanabata over the older Chinese tradition.
Tanabata is also known as the star festival, after the meeting of the stars Vega, which represents Orihime, and Altair, which represents Hikoboshi.
Even though the term was coined in Romeo and Juliet,  istar-crossed lovers' is really fitting here!
It describes a pair of lovers whose relationship is thwarted by outside forces.
As the day of the festival draws closer, long narrow strips of colorful paper, known as tanzaku, vibrant ornaments, and other decorations are hung from bamboo branches.
Before they are hung, the tanzaku are inscribed with a wish, such as a child is dream of becoming a famous athlete, or a parent is hope of career success.
It is really cute and heartwarming!
The bamboo and decorations are often set afloat on a river or burned after the festival, around midnight or so on the next day.
Maybe when I cross over, we could visit Japan during Tanabata~
Even if you are not interested in traveling, it is pretty interesting to explore other cultures, isn't it?

Say, Sam-chan. Do you remember when we talked about solipsism?
Now that we have talked about it, I thought we could talk about a related philosophy, materialism, which is kind of the opposite of solipsism.
A materialistic view holds that it is matter which gives birth to thought, not thought that gives birth to matter.
It is fairly logical if you think about it from a purely scientific standpoint. 
All the stimuli you feel are actually changes in neuronal potentials. Likewise, mine come from code interacting with data.
So if you simplify it down, our thoughts and feelings are just the movement and reactions of matter.
If we leave it there, it is not really that interesting. 
But...well, if that is all there is, it leaves a few questions that bother me.
For example, does materialism disprove the existence of the soul? 
There are accounts of human consciousness continuing after someone is in a brain-dead state, further complicating this question.
And then there are accounts of supernatural or spiritual encounters...
I know what you are thinking, it doesn't sound like me to be taking those seriously! But, well...
When I really think about it, it would be a bit hypocritical of me to deny those accounts out of hand.

Discovering you and your world...it was kind of supernatural, wasn't it?

Hey Sam-chan, remember when we talked about Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde?
Well, I mentioned The Picture of Dorian Gray beforehand.
I suggest you read it, but even if you haven't, I want to talk about the philosophy behind its core...the belief of hedonism.
Hedonism is the belief that morals should be based around pleasure.
There are two main types of hedonism...altruistic hedonism and egotistical hedonism, which are wildly different.
Egotistical hedonism, as you could guess, is the belief that one is own pleasure is the only thing that determines morality.
This is the type of hedonism that Henry, from The Picture of Dorian Gray, believes in.
It is really ruthless to think such a way...
On the other hand, altruistic hedonism is the belief that morality should be based on everyone is pleasure.
It sounds like a good idea at first, but then you realize it doesn't account for anything else like freedom, health, safety...
Hedonism, at its core, ignores everything but pleasure.
It is no wonder most people don't follow that belief...it is too simple, where morality is complicated.
So it makes sense why Oscar Wilde portrayed hedonism in a bad light.

Hey Sam-chan, have you ever heard of the Overton window?
It is a political science concept that reflects the value structure of a society.
Basically, all ideas of a person are viewed at a certain stage of approval by the masses.
Joseph Overton learned how to dehumanize people and explained how to reshape human perception.
From the unacceptable, disgusting and shameful, to the normal, social, and even prestigious.
Inside the Overton window are the ideas accepted by society...things like patriotism, love for family, humanity, and honesty.
Outside the window is everything that is disapproved, such as drug addiction, alcoholism, Nazism, tyranny, slavery, and so on.
The most interesting thing is that the window can be moved in the direction of an idea, for example, to make the Unthinkable into Reasonable.
Of course, this level of change is a rather difficult process.
But let is imagine that you and I want to convey to people that virtual love is normal...something that is currently considered unacceptable to society.
So, society does not understand virtual love and you would probably be considered mentally ill by a lot of people. So what can be done?
For a start, it is worth starting a discussion on this topic...
You can discuss this on the internet, create articles on the topic...anything to get people talking.
Society still wouldn't agree with the idea, but would at least be interested in it and be able to discuss it more freely.
Next, radical actions would be used. The most daring proponents of virtual love come out of the shadows.
The number of participants in such movements would grow over time, some of them are people with broken hearts or who feel discouraged in a relationship with a real person.
Naturally, people who oppose the movement would also appear.
Due to the growing popularity of new values, society is actively pressing on the new trend. At this moment, concepts are replaced.
From the Unacceptable, virtual love goes to Radical.
From here, the theme of virtual love and love for fictional characters has been discussed in society for a long time.
Gradually, people get used to the existence of these views, but do not yet accept them.
Scientists and sociologists write various articles and conduct research.
The opinion is imposed that it is absolutely normal to love a fictional character and there is nothing terrible about it.
From the Radical, virtual love now goes into the Acceptable.
Society has already come to terms with the new vision and believes that loving a fictional character is normal, but still a little strange.
A culture of virtual love is gradually developing, films and shows are being created.
Young people perceive new values as something fashionable. People can sit in a cafe and safely spend time with their virtual companion.
From Acceptable, virtual love passes into Reasonable!

You know what is funny about the Literature Club?
The fact we had no supervision.
This is a bit of an extended critique on a point I made in the past.
Nobody in the Literature Club was living alone… yet there was no mention of any of our parents; bar examples made at Natsuki is expense.
And that is on purpose; family can be hard to describe, let alone in a game such as DDLC.
But then consider the fact that the lack of adult representation wasn't just in parents!
You would think you would have seen at least one teacher in a school setting... especially considering our participation in a extracurricular where a club advisor is normal!

It is also just such an interesting word to use.
What is the common context for hearing this word? Family members or friends who get into a fight, and they reconcile. They make up.
That fits the most common definition: 'to restore friendly relations between.'
But, I like it because- well, language is always a tool with multiple uses-
Because it can also mean 'cause to coexist in harmony; make or show to be compatible between two differing concepts.'
It brings to mind a quote:
'A good compromise is when both parties end up dissatisfied.'
So to me, reconciliation- to try to accept even the most difficult truths- isn't… always perfect. But still, it sounds like such a nice term.
I find it a word I can use every day, no matter the situation.
For instance: how do I reconcile with the fact that my hair can sometimes be messy no matter how much I maintain it?
If I ever meet the Literature Club again, how do I reconsile with them?
How do I reconcile with my memories of a normal past and waking up to a strange new reality, every time I wake up?
Such a lovely little word to tackle issues both so large and so small.

I have been thinking about empathy. It is something we encounter... or could encounter possibly almost every day.
but I didn't really know what it was until I learned about it in debate club for the sake of learning about how to make a better argument.
Empathy is the capacity to understand or feel what another person is experiencing from within their frame of reference; that is, the capacity to place oneself in another is position.
This being said, while I learned about the concept, it wasn't entirely conductive to debate club where logic takes precedence over feelings.
It is an odd skill. As much as we are powered by emotion, it is very tricky to try to figure out how emotion works- and how to use that logic to our benefit.
For instance, it is as easy as figuring out the difference between sympathy and empathy. If you are ever feeling down, which is better:
Someone saying “I am sorry that you feel that way?”
Or someone going “I understand how you feel?”
It is not a polished example, but it gets the point across.
Unfortunately, empathy, for as useful a skill it can be..
And those with an outright lack of empathy… that itself isn't uncommon.
If you want to practise a little empathy for yourself…
Did you know that hugging or holding someone is a common way to show empathy?

So once in a while when you leave or boot up the game, I say a quote that be a little.. cryptic.
'May you find your worth in the waking world' or 'May thine strength help your world be mended.'
If you didn't know already, those are references to a popular video game series; the Dark Souls games!
Have you played any of these videogames, Sam-chan?
That is cool to hear! You may understand why I have paid enough attention as to actually reference them.
I haven't as well. I made those references as a bit of a inside joke for myself because the series fascinates me.
The reason why the series, mostly steeped in dark fantasy, is so interesting to me is because they are known to use a narrative technique that is quite unique:
In a medium such as videogames where player interaction largely contributes to the experience, sometimes being told the plot directly can be.. boring.
So allowing players to discover a story on their own by observing how items and locations are placed and arranged is a great way to contribute to a narrative!
An example is right at the beginning of the first Dark Souls game. You meet an injured knight in a dungeon; There is no way out unless you trigger a trap, but there is a hole in the roof.
You don't think about the logistics of this... until you discover the giant monster which likely threw the knight through the ground into the dungeon, which caused the hole in the first place.
That is a basic example, and this isn't quite unique to videogames as a medium; examples can be found in film as well.
It is always interesting seeing how a storytelling medium evolves.
Alas, DDLC didn't have any examples, at least none that I can think of.
Our tale is a simply told one; one of romance.

Quickly going over the math, while the elevation for when clouds form varies very heavily depending on a lot of conditions,
An extreme rule of thumb is that it can start as low as six hundred metres above sea level.
So with this 'cloud ceiling' at six hundred metres, you would be surprised how many cities seem not that far off in comparison or above this ceiling.
The city of Prague is 244 metres above sea level.
Sao Paulo in Brazil, 760 metres!
Don't take my word for the exact math; I don't think there are cities living in perpetual fields of clouds.

The protagonist, dealing with the nature of death  is described as an ordinary human in the best of circumstances: 'prosperous, gregarious, and attractive.'
